title: Short-term energy fixes don't help: Origin CEO
text:
'If we continue down the path there will be no-one investing in anything without government underwriting or support because that's where we are right now."

But Mr Calabria's comments that coal is "the wrong type of generation to firm renewables" and that extending the life of coal plants without a strong carbon signal "will extend the uncertainty we are all facing today" sparked an accusation from Senator Canavan that the suppliers were just profiting from the dearth of investment.

"I reckon we should do the opposite of what the big energy companies say because they are a big reason why we are in this mess," the Senator tweeted.

The minister's comments deepen a feud between the Morrison government and energy suppliers over an ongoing drought in investment in fast-start power stations to complement rising renewable generation, with the result that security of supply could be threatened.

While the suppliers argue the ever-changing rules, short-term measures and lack of a long-term emissions target make it difficult to justify hundreds of millions of dollars of investments in new gas or pumped hydro plants, the government has accused them of deliberately not investing to keep prices high.

But Mr Calabria rejected suggestions that relations between industry and government had reached a fresh low.

"There will be things we disagree on...but overall I would say that relationships are pretty constructive," he said. "Their focus is very much the short-term fixes."

Federal energy minister Angus Taylor insisted the government was taking "strong action" to reduce emissions, pointing to the $3.5 billion Climate Solutions package that sets out how the country will meet its 2030 target.

Federal Energy Minister Angus Taylor has again ruled out a price on carbon. AAP

"The government is not considering a carbon price," Mr Taylor noted.

But Mr Calabria said that however difficult it was, a pathway for emissions reduction beyond 2030 had to be set to give confidence for long-term investment in cleaner but also reliable supply.

He said he wasn't concerned about the role of federal government-owned Snowy Hydro in the sector but said government participation was "now stretching to another level" with the underwriting scheme for new on-demand generation.

Origin is still considering investing in a pumped hydro expansion at its Shoalhaven project south of Sydney and fast-start generation at other sites, but Mr Calabria said the company needed to understand what would come out of the government's underwriting scheme and other factors to go ahead.

The government is expected to finalise underwriting measures for several gas and pumped hydro projects under its Underwriting New Generation Investments scheme by the year-end. "All of that just goes into the mix of future supply and demand," Mr Calabria said.
description: Origin Energy chief executive Frank Calabria has called for clarity around government participation in the energy sector and for a "calm rest" from short-term measures.
